intro: Gilia tenuituba f. violacea, commonly known as the violet-stemmed gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its slender, often purplish stems and showy, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its flowers are usually pale violet to blue in color, with five petals and prominent yellow stamens. The species is noted for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its delicate appearance.
